basics.name: Muhammad Sulaiman
basics.label: Ph.D Candidate
basics.summary: I am a fifth-year Ph.D. student at the University of Waterloo. I am passionate about using artificial intelligence for autonomous management and orchestration of 5G and beyond networks.

work.name: Information Processing and Transmission (IPT) Lab, National University of Sciences and Technology
work.summary: Designed a CSI-based activity recognition system leveraging commodity WiFi hardware and USRPs with GNU Radio, enhancing applications in security, healthcare, and smart environments.
highlights: Developed a CSI-based Live Activity Recognition Framework using commodity hardware.

work.name: University of Waterloo
work.summary: Conducting research on AI-driven management of 5G networks. Developed digital twin models, novel slice admission control frameworks, and dynamic resource scaling algorithms to improve automation, QoS assurance, and spectral efficiency.
highlights: Developed a novel slice modeling approach.
Developed a novel RL-based framework for joint slicing and admission control of 5G slices.
Developed an online slice admission control framework with a theoretical worst-case performance guarantee.
Developed primal-dual and RL based frameworks for dynamic resource scaling of 5G slices.

work.name: Ericsson
work.summary: Designing and validating AI-native link adaptation algorithms for real-world 5G deployments, enabling dynamic modulation and coding scheme selection to enhance spectral efficiency.

projects.name: 5G Testbed and Use-case Deployment
projects.summary: Containerized and automated the deployment of a fully functional 5G testbed integrating srsRAN, OAI, and Open5GS. Enabled end-to-end experimentation with AI-driven algorithms and validation of 5G applications such as VR and cloud gaming.
highlights: Automated deployment on Kubernetes with multi-vendor 5G core and RAN components.
Integrated VR and cloud-gaming applications to demonstrate low-latency capabilities.
Provided an experimental platform for evaluating AI/ML-based orchestration solutions.

projects.name: Network Digital Twins
projects.summary: Developed AI-based digital twins of 5G slices and VNFs for accurate, scalable, and generalizable modeling. Enabled composable per-VNF models for predicting performance under varying configurations and workloads.
highlights: Built differentiable models using Bayesian NNs, RNNs, and Transformers.
Released open datasets and reproducible pipelines for research use.
Published results in IEEE/IFIP NOMS 2025 (vNetRunner) and IEEE TNSM 2025 (MicroOpt).

projects.name: Dynamic Resource Management
projects.summary: Designed reinforcement learning and optimization-based algorithms for dynamic resource allocation in 5G networks. Addressed both resource efficiency and QoS constraints in slice operations.
highlights: Developed constrained RL frameworks for resource scaling of 5G slices (Best Paper NOMS 2023).
Formulated primal-dual optimization methods for near-optimal allocation with guarantees.
Created the MicroOpt framework for model-driven slice optimization.

projects.name: AI-native Link Adaptation
projects.summary: Collaborated with Ericsson to design AI-native link adaptation algorithms for real-world 5G networks. Leveraged DRL to improve modulation and coding scheme (MCS) selection under dynamic channel conditions.
highlights: Validated algorithms in live network settings with improved spectral efficiency.
Outperformed state-of-the-art heuristics using deep reinforcement learning.
Work featured in an Ericsson press release (2025).

projects.name: Adaptive Network Monitoring
projects.summary: Engineered a cloud-native monitoring framework for dynamic KPI collection in 5G network slices. Designed to balance observability with reduced overhead at large scale.
highlights: Built on Prometheus, Grafana, Spark, Kafka, and Hadoop.
Implemented adaptive granularity adjustment to minimize monitoring load.
Published in IEEE TNSM 2024 (MonArch).

projects.name: CSI-based Activity Recognition
projects.summary: Designed a CSI-based activity recognition system using commodity WiFi hardware and USRPs with GNU Radio. Applied deep learning to wireless signal patterns for human activity classification.
highlights: Developed and released a framework for live CSI-based recognition.
Enhanced applications in smart homes, healthcare, and security.
Published in IEEE WCNC Workshops 2020 (TrueDetect).
